speaker: MALE AGENT
line: Just a routine background check. Now, to the best of your knowledge has Mr. Wisnowski ever used any illegal drugs? Which illegal drugs?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, in the time that you worked with... Ms. Ermentrout did you find her to be a trustworthy person? Punctual. Punctual is good.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, no, ma'am. This is just a routine background check. Mr... Mr. Garber is not in any legal trouble whatsoever. Yeah. Okay. Thanks for your time.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully maybe if we get really lucky next time they'll let us clean toilet bowls.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You ready to quit?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. That would make way too many people way too happy.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully. I'm on my way.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I've been called into Kersh's office.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Just me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Just you? Don't forget your toilet brush. No. No, ma'am, not you.

speaker: AD KERSH
line: Agent.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sir.

speaker: AD KERSH
line: Dana Scully, this is Agent Peyton Ritter with the Bureau's New York office.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Agent Ritter.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Hi.

speaker: AD KERSH
line: Show her what you have.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Uh, well, our office is currently updating its case filing system. While I was involved in this project-- scanning old crime scene photographs into the computer-- I came across this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Margareta Stoller age 57, cause of death-- an overdose of Nitraz....

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Take a look at when they found her.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A NEIGHBOR CALLED THE POLICE AT 11:14 p.m.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: So what's wrong with that picture?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The clock says that it's 45 minutes earlier. Well, a clock can be wrong.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: They certainly can. So, I checked the Post from the following day. These are straight from their photo files.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hmm. Almost an hour and a half later.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Two different negatives, same photographer. The guy's name is Alfred Fellig. He's rattled around Manhattan for years. Apparently a stringer for the wire services and on-call guy for NYPD.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And you suspect this man Fellig? You think that Mrs. Stoller wasn't a suicide?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: This guy's into taking pictures, right? So I'm thinking, what if... what if he poisons this woman and gets his jollies by snapping a few of her dead body then winds up back in the same apartment an hour later, after Midtown North calls him over to do the job.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's quite a theory.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Yeah. Well, the thing of it is he might have done it on more than one occasion. Now, I sifted through probably 2,000 of his police photos. Now, these three have measurable solar shadows. And since we know the location in each case...

speaker: SCULLY
line: You can tell the time of day by the shadows.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Right. And with it, these three are looking every bit as hinky.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You've got another suicide here a heart attack and a very obvious murder for which another man was convicted. There's no consistent MO.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: There's no consistent anything. I could sure use your help.

speaker: AD KERSH
line: Agent, would you step outside, please.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Sure.

speaker: AD KERSH
line: I would say he has a promising career ahead of him. So did you... at one time.

speaker: AD KERSH
line: With your expertise in forensic pathology you would be a substantial asset to this investigation. I know it would provide more challenge to you than running background checks.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Agent Mulder and I will begin immediately.

speaker: AD KERSH
line: Agent Mulder's a lost cause. I'm taking the chance you're not. It's you and Ritter. Do not let me down.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Hmm?

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you doing?

speaker: MULDER
line: Being nosy. Eating my heart out. They're sending you on an X-File.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's not an X-File.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's not what I'm reading. I'm thinking murder by telekinesis. I'm thinking maybe a shamanistic death touch. I'm thinking about the Muslim superstition that to photograph someone is to steal their soul.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thank you. All very helpful.

speaker: MULDER
line: So they're splitting us up, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: No?

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is a one-time thing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Who told you that? Obviously, if you do a good job they're not going to stick you back here.

speaker: MULDER
line: Right?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Agent Scully we're all set.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Peyton Ritter, this is Fox Mulder.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: It's a pleasure to meet you, Fox.

speaker: MULDER
line: A pleasure to meet you, … Peyton.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We should get going.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Off to New York.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Alfred Fellig-- what can you tell us about him?

speaker: DESK SARGEANT
line: What's to tell? He's one of about 10,000 people in town who have an official license to piss people off.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, he sometimes doubles as a crime scene photographer for your precinct.

speaker: DESK SARGEANT
line: Yeah, he comes in, snaps a picture. Keeps to himself.

speaker: SCULLY
line: There's not much in the way of personal information there.

speaker: DESK SARGEANT
line: There's not supposed to be. It's just a yearly renewal form.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Would you happen to know when the original background check was done?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Here he is again. Yearly renewal dating back to January, 1970 but still no original.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think I've got it. 1964.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Old-timer. Anything interesting?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: What you doing?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Take a look at this.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: The guy's a regular Dick Clark. I don't know what to tell you, Dana. Other than the fact that this guy's always been a geezer, this is looking like a dead end.

speaker: YOUNG MAN WITH LIGHT UP SNEAKERS
line: Help! Help! Somebody call the police! Man, what do you want from me? Are you crazy?

speaker: YOUNG MAN WITH LIGHT UP SNEAKERS
line: Help! Help me, please! Come on lady, please! Help me! Man, what do you want from me, man? No! No no no no!

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: The prints are Alfred Fellig's. Positive match right off his 1964 background check. I took the liberty of slipping them into the SAFIS database. First thing this morning, boom! Up they came.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're thinking this was Fellig's work?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: It's a lock. The wound measurements match with the knife. I'd say he got pretty sloppy in his old age.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's this?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: A whole lot of blood.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. I got that.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: It's pretty clear he took a second victim.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where's the second body?

speaker: NY DETECTIVE
line: They found your boy.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Fellig? Where?

speaker: NY DETECTIVE
line: Home watching TV. They're bringing him in now.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Yes!

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Check. Check. January 4, 11:36 a.m. 15th precinct, Manhattan.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Alfred Fellig.

speaker: FELLIG
line: Hello.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: You're a photographer. I've seen, uh... seen some of your work. You, uh... specialize in some pretty dark subject matter. You're, uh... you're around death a lot. It must... it must fascinate you. Am I... boring you, Mr. Fellig?

speaker: FELLIG
line: Ask me a question already.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: All right. I want to know how you always happen to be Johnny-on-the-spot every time somebody dies. You're always there to take the picture. How does that happen?

speaker: FELLIG
line: I have a... a nose for news.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mr. Fellig your fingerprints were found on a murder weapon at a crime scene. Could you give us a full accounting of your activities last night?

speaker: FELLIG
line: The Bronx. I was on the job. Saw some jibone stealing a kid's tennis shoes. He chased me. Ran off.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: He ran off? Some... unidentified murderer.

speaker: FELLIG
line: I guess I could identify him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Your fingerprints were found on the knife. How did they get there?

speaker: FELLIG
line: He left the knife behind. I guess I touched it... briefly.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why would you do that? Were you injured Mr. Fellig? You seem to be in pain. Were you attacked? We found other blood at the crime scene and, when we have it tested I'm wondering if we're going to learn that it's yours.

speaker: FELLIG
line: I got cut some.

speaker: SCULLY
line: May we see?

speaker: SCULLY
line: May I help you?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Hey. Hey, take Mr. Fellig to get his blood drawn. Photograph his back, too.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Hey, I'm confused. I thought we were trying to bust this guy not look for reasons to let him go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I thought we were looking for the truth.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hi. My name is Fox Mulder. We used to sit next to each other at the FBI.

speaker: MULDER
line: How's your X-File coming?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it's not... We haven't made much headway. We arrested Alfred Fellig and we just released him.

speaker: MULDER
line: You can't hold him? What about the stabbing?

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you know about that?

speaker: MULDER
line: I told you I'm nosy. Why are you letting him go?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, we were able to pull another set of prints off of the knife. They belong to a convicted murderer by the name of Malcolm Wiggins.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That and the fact that Fellig's blood was found all over the crime scene tells me that his story checks out. At least that particular story, anyway.

speaker: MULDER
line: But you still think Fellig's a murderer, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know what to think. He's, uh... unusual.

speaker: MULDER
line: As in he, uh, plugs up like a cork when you stab him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, where are you getting this stuff?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, young man Ritter has been sending progress reports to Kersh. My computer may have inadvertently intercepted a few of those. He's got nice things to say about you, though... mostly. Why don't you let me do a little background check on Fellig for you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on. It's, you know... it's what I do now. I'm getting good at it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm parked around the block.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Fellig's asleep. I haven't seen him move in over four hours. Have a lovely evening.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mr. Fellig, open up, please!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Explain this.

speaker: FELLIG
line: What?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You took that photo an hour before police arrived. You then purposely covered up that fact by photographing the scene again.

speaker: FELLIG
line: I don't think I remember that one.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You have, Mr. Fellig, a long and uncanny history of being the first person at the scene of a death. You also have a history of covering up that fact. Why?

speaker: FELLIG
line: Am I under arrest again?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you a murderer?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, then explain yourself, sir. Because, I promise you until you do, you will not get a moment's peace.

speaker: FELLIG
line: You want to take a ride with me? You come with me. I'll show you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's been an hour. Are we going to drive around all night?

speaker: FELLIG
line: Yeah. This is it. This is what I do. Looking for the shot.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What shot?

speaker: FELLIG
line: The shot.

speaker: FELLIG
line: Her. She's about to die.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What... what are you talking about?

speaker: FELLIG
line: It could happen in the next minute, in the next hour but it'll happen. It's as plain as day.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look, Mr... Fellig, I don't know what you're planning but nobody here is going to die.

speaker: FELLIG
line: I'm not planning anything. I'm just here to tell you what's going to happen.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That … that woman right there is going to be murdered?

speaker: FELLIG
line: I didn't say "murdered." She's a smoker. She might die of lung cancer. The "how" is always a surprise. I... I just always know "when."

speaker: SCULLY
line: You want me to believe that?

speaker: HOOKER
line: Get out of my face. Get off me!

speaker: SCULLY
line: FBI! Don't move!

speaker: HOOKER HASSLER
line: Damn, man! Where'd you come from?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Shut up! Get down! Back up!

speaker: HOOKER
line: You're not such a big man now!

speaker: HOOKER HASSLER
line: That gun ain't mine, Red.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You all right?

speaker: HOOKER
line: I'm out of here.

speaker: (NEXT MORNING.  8
line: 00. Precinct station. AGENT RITTER angrily runs up to SCULLY who is processing the HOOKER HASSLER. SCULLY looks dirty and exhausted.)

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Dana, what the hell is going on?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Assault and possession of an unregistered handgun. I'll be with you in a minute.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Why didn't you call me sooner?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I apologize.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: What, you blew off the surveillance?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No offense, but the surveillance was blown before I got there.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: So, wait, wait-- you blew off the surveillance and what, took a little joyride with him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I confronted Fellig. I questioned him further about his involvement in the deaths that he photographed. Is that okay with you?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: What did he say?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He said that he can tell when people are about to die. Look, if New York passes a Good Samaritan law we might be able to nail him on that but other than that, I doubt we're going to get him for murder.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Wrong. Let me show you something.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: They picked up Mr. Wiggins last night. Now, he says that it was Fellig who killed that kid in the alley, not him. He said he just happened along and he had to fight for his life.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A convicted murderer half Fellig's age.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: He said he would have come in on his own but he said he was afraid we wouldn't have believed him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's right. Tell me, Ritter, did he have any help concocting that story?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Look, Fellig is a murderer. Whether or not he did this specific one, I don't care-- not if it buys me a few days in the box with him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No judge is going to issue a warrant based on this.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: No, no, no. I know the judge. We'll have it by noon.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: You know, Kersh warned me about you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, he did?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Yeah-- you and your partner. God knows his reputation precedes him so I guess I should have seen this coming. You muck up my case, and Kersh'll hear about it. Are we clear, Dana?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Scully.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And we're done with this conversation.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully, uh, how's that X-File coming? And before you tell me that it's not an X-File...

speaker: SCULLY
line: It is.

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Alfred Fellig seems to know an awful lot about death.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, yeah? Well, that's not surprising, given that he's reached the ripe old age of 149.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me?

speaker: MULDER
line: I did a little low-tech background check on him. This stuff is so old that they don't even keep it on record on the computer but Alfred Fellig doesn't exist before 1964 but one Henry Strand does. He applied for a press pass from the Jersey City police in 1939 at the age of 53. His prints match Fellig's.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But Mulder, that must be some kind of a mistake.

speaker: MULDER
line: You think? Because this Henry Strand does not exist before 1939. However, one L.H. Rice is on record as having sat for the New York State civil service exam. Now, the records don't show whether he passed or not but his thumbprint? Fellig's. Want to know what L.H. Rice's birthday is? April 4, 1849. I'm not good at math, but I'm figuring that's a whole lot of candles on the cake.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I have spent time with this man and-and he can't be more than 65 years old.

speaker: MULDER
line: I-I think that's what he wants you to think. Now we're talking about a guy for whom the phrase "life in prison" carries some seriously weighty connotations. I think you should get to him before he vanishes and becomes someone else.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You are going to be arrested, Mr. Fellig, in two hours, charged with murder, and this time you won't be able to just change your name.

speaker: FELLIG
line: I showed you what I do last night. I just take the pictures.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What you showed me was a contemptible lack of compassion for another human being. You showed me that you profit off of people's deaths. Now, why shouldn't you go to prison?

speaker: FELLIG
line: What, do you want me to cry for them? You want me to make like I feel sorry for them? I don't. Lucky bastards. Every one of them.

speaker: SCULLY
line: "Lucky"?

speaker: FELLIG
line: I'm just there to get the shot. I don't take those people. He does.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who's he?

speaker: FELLIG
line: That's him. He's the one who takes them.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're saying that this is a photograph of Death itself?

speaker: FELLIG
line: It's a glimpse, just a glimpse. It's closer than I've gotten in... well, I-I can't even count the years.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And this is the shot that you spoke of-- this is... what you try and get?

speaker: FELLIG
line: Mm-hmm.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mr. Fellig, I know... that you know more about photography than I do but this is just a lens flare.

speaker: FELLIG
line: You're right. I do know more about photography than you do.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Okay, I mean... mmm … for the sake of argument... why bother? I mean, why... why take a picture of Death?

speaker: FELLIG
line: So I can look into his face. So I can die. Pills don't work. Razors... … gas... bridges--- I can't tell you how many bridges I've jumped off of. All I get is wet. I got left behind. I don't want to be here anymore. I can't even remember a time when I did. And... this... this is all I know... to do.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know I don't believe you.

speaker: FELLIG
line: Yes, you do. That's why you're here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How is it you know when people are about to die?

speaker: FELLIG
line: Oh... You chase it long enough you pick it up.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it's me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hi.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Those other two names that you said that Fellig went by-- Strand and Rice...?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Henry Srand and L.H. rice.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about Louis Brady?

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh, no, but there's a... there's, like, a big gap before 1939.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Will you check it out for me?

speaker: MULDER
line: Absolutely, yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm sticking here to make sure he doesn't bolt. Louis Brady, Mulder. Tell me what you find out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mr. Fellig?

speaker: FELLIG
line: Oops. Excuse me. I have some film out. Hold on a second.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Ritter.

speaker: MULDER
line: Agent Ritter, it's Agent Mulder. Is Agent Scully there with you?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: No, she's not. Nobody seems to able to find her.

speaker: MULDER
line: Me neither, and D.C. Cellular says her phone is turned off.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: What can I do for you, Agent?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, you can find her for me.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Listen, Agent Mulder, I'm on my way to arrest Alfred Fellig.

speaker: MULDER
line: Good, because that's where I think she is. And you were right, Fellig is a murderer. Under the name of Louis Brady, he suffocated two patients in a Connecticut hospital. He says he meant to catch up with death. One year into his prison sentence he walked off a work detail. The manhunt never officially ceased.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: When was this?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa-- when?

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, Ritter, don't sweat the math. It's him. Just get there and find Agent Scully.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: All right. I'm on it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, most people want to live forever.

speaker: FELLIG
line: Most people are idiots. Which is one of the reasons I don't.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think you're wrong. How can you have too much life? There's too much to learn, to experience.

speaker: FELLIG
line: 75 years... is enough. Take my word for it. You live forever, sooner or later you start to think about the big thing you're missing and that everybody else gets to find out about but you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about love?

speaker: FELLIG
line: What, does that last forever? 40 years ago I drove down to the city hall, down to the hall of records... record archives, whatever they call it. I wanted to look up my wife. It... bothered me I couldn't remember her name. Love lasts... 75 years, if you're lucky. You don't want to be around when it's gone.

speaker: FELLIG
line: Count your blessings.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why are you this way? I mean, if this is true give me something in the way of proof... help me find some science that I can hang this on.

speaker: FELLIG
line: It has nothing to do with science. Someone took my place.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Took your place?

speaker: FELLIG
line: I don't know her name. I don't think I ever knew it. I had yellow fever way the hell back then when it killed half of New York. Washington Square Park was a common grave they had so many bodies. They'd bury them shallow. They wrapped them in-in yellow sheets and the yellow sheets would stick up through the mud. I was in a city-run contagion ward. I was out of my head with fever... out of my mind. And I saw him-- saw Death. Wish I had had a camera then. At first, I... just saw him out of the corner of my eye. Then he got bolder and he started flitting around the room and he'd take this person and he'd take that person and I never saw his face. I didn't want to see his face. I figured if I saw it, he'd take me, too.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But he didn't.

speaker: FELLIG
line: No. There was a nurse. She did the best she could. Back then, medical science was... they couldn't find their ass with both hands-- they still can't-- but she did the best she could. She sat with me, held my hand and I was on my deathbed and he came for me. I didn't look at him. I closed my eyes and turned my head. I didn't tell her not to look at him. I wanted her to look at him... I wanted her to look at him instead of me. And then I came to and the fever broke. They were carrying her out wrapped up in a yellow sheet. Since that time I realized you got to be careful what you wish for. I missed my chance. You're very lucky, you know that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: What do you mean? Wait a minute. Say what's on your mind. You mean lucky like the others? You want me to believe that I'm about to die?

speaker: FELLIG
line: I just want to take the picture.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You took my picture. You took my picture last night. Is this why?

speaker: FELLIG
line: No, that was different.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not going to die! Turn that off.

speaker: FELLIG
line: No.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Turn it off right now! Put it down!

speaker: FELLIG
line: There is nothing to be done for it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You took my phone. Why?

speaker: FELLIG
line: Please, just give me a chance.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What don't you want me to know?

speaker: FELLIG
line: He's coming….

speaker: SCULLY
line: What don't you want me to know!?

speaker: FELLIG
line: He's coming and you should just make your peace.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Shut up!

speaker: FELLIG
line: He's here.

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Agent?

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Oh, god. Oh, no, no, no, no, no, no, no...

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: Come on... Come on... Dammit!

speaker: AGENT RITTER
line: We need some help in here!

speaker: FELLIG
line: Do you see him? Do you see him? Don't look. Close your eyes.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're a lucky man.

speaker: MULDER
line: Coroner's report came back on Fellig. Says he died of a single gunshot wound. That's all it said. Well, I, uh... talked to your doctor and... he says you're doing great. You're making the fastest recovery he's ever seen.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, Mulder, I don't even know how I entertained the thought. People don't live forever.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no, I-I... I think he would have. I-I just think that … that death only looks for you... once you seek its opposite.
